docs.lead_paragraph: THE 45-year-old man tried to hold back his tears as he sat in the Bellevue psychiatric emergency interview room. He was telling a doctor why he had suddenly started shouting in a Manhattan church earlier that day. The priest had called the police to take him away after he refused to leave. The patient, a 20-year military veteran, explained how he had been increasingly plagued by the desire to jump out the window of his 10th-floor room in a hotel near Times Square and had gone to the church in desperation. ''I asked God to help me,'' he said. ''I wanted God to kill me or cure me.'' It was his first visit to an emergency room or to a psychiatrist, he said, and he was plainly embarrassed that his self-punishing drives had brought him to this unexpected place.
